I don't understand what people are getting so angry about. You're just providing information on the topic of refugee camps. Don't listen to those who are calling this 'propaganda', or any other xenophobic bullshit people are spouting on about. If the people that commented those things had the same thing happen to them, they would view the issue VERY differently. People should consider Rawls' thought experiment, the 'veil of ignorance':

People making political decisions imagine that they know nothing about the particular talents, abilities, tastes, social class, and positions they will have within a social order. When such parties are selecting the principles for distribution of rights, positions, and resources in the society in which they will live, this "veil of ignorance" prevents them from knowing who will receive a given distribution of rights, positions, and resources in that society. For example, for a proposed society in which 50% of the population is kept in slavery, it follows that on entering the new society there is a 50% likelihood that the participant would be a slave. The idea is that parties subject to the veil of ignorance will make choices based upon moral considerations, since they will not be able to make choices based on their own self- or class-interest - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veil_of_ignorance

Thanks for putting out this video. Here in Australia we have some massive issues regarding the refugee camps off our shores. I'm sure people around the world have heard of Manus Island and Nauru. We as the public have basically been barred from knowing the situations over there, although horrific tales of all forms of abuse have made it outside from people who have been willing to speak out even knowing they may face a prison sentence and from refugees who have left the facilities or taken a heavy risk to communicate whilst still in limbo. Although Manus is now shutting down, the lives of those still there may take a turn for the worst, more so than now. Nauru is set to stay and so too are the many still trapped there, unsure of the future. There was one small victory, though, the Australian government has agreed to pay $70 million in compensation to the refugees on Manus in a class action (although they still deny that any physical or psychological abuse had occurred). Anyway, this video was insightful and has shown to me that it is possible to create a camp that looks out for the basic needs and human rights of those occupying it.

And it can happen quickly. You could go to work one morning and find yourself a refugee by lunch time. Escaping with what ever you happen to have, with your family (if you're lucky) and completely depending on the charity of others to survive.
Will those others say "No, not in my back yard." or will they say, "Welcome, we will help you as much as we can."
So, which will you choose to say, assuming you are the one the refugee comes to for help.
You may not be responsible for the refugee's plight, nor do you owe them anything, but if you were in their place, then you will be asking for help from someone who owes you nothing and is in no way responsible for you.

Okay, these comments are getting insanely negative, so here's a disclaimer: I am not looking for an argument, to debate stats, or to crucify AsapSCIENCE for this video. I just want to put in my two cents.

That said, this video disappoints me for a couple reasons. For one, it isn't about science. I really like the majority of this channel's scientific content. That's what I subscribed for, not this. You have another channel for this, Greg and Mitch (previously AsapThought), where you answer more varied kinds of questions, including humanitarian ones. I was actually looking forward to the actual science behind building a refugee camp. Breaking down the materials, the costs, how much time it takes to build, the population it could support, and other stats is what I expected, yet you let me and other fans of yours who were legitimately interested in the science behind this topic down.

As if that wasn't enough, what you put out instead of a scientific video was a left-leaning propaganda piece. Normally, I would be hesitant to label anyone's opinions "propaganda", but you made it very obvious. You are clearly biased towards refugees here. Now, you have a right to your opinions. I'm not bashing you for having an opinion or for exercising free speech, but I came here for facts. Facts aren't biased. They tell the truth and leave it up to those who learn the information to come to their own conclusions. We only got facts in the intro, and then we got a few facts about the specific camp you were in throughout the video. If this had been a factual video on refugees and their lives that utilized the camp in Lesvos as a case study without clearly trying to push a political agenda, I probably would have been okay with that. I still would have preferred the science, but I would not be turned off by a video like that.

I don't care about your political views, and none of my political views are the reason why I do not like this video. Regardless of whether or not I agree with you, I do not want non-scientific, suggestive material from you guys. Give me the facts and let me come to my own conclusions. I may have been more forgiving if you didn't title the video the way you did and declared it a special video, but in the video itself you stated, and I quote, "We came here to talk about the actual logistics of building a refugee camp, but you are just consistently meeting people and talking to people and realizing the humanity of it all." You ignored your goal of educating your audience in an unbiased fashion on a topic in order to push your opinions, and that makes me wary of continuing to subscribe to you. You can do better than this.

Alright so seeing this discussion going on in the comments I'll drop some statistics from my own home country, the Netherlands. According to our central bureau of statistics the amount of Syrian refugees from 2013 to 2016 is 32.520 with 2.230 in 2013, 8.750 in 2014, 18.675 in 2015 and 2.865 in 2016 (do note that this does not take into acount the family of said family that comes after them).

Unfortunately there are no crime statistics for Syrian refugees so nothing can be said about that yet.

There are however statistics about crimes commited from people with an Iraqi background, this is 2.8% of the population which has been steadily decreasing amongst other crimes since it's 5% in 2005 with small spikes occuring in the years 2007 and 2010 and no real peaks sinse the refugee crisis started (it has even been decreasing quicker since 2013)

The refugee population from Iraq was 535 in 2013, 615 in 2014, 3.010 in 2015 and 960 in 2016 ranking up to 5120 refugees in total.

There are no refugee numbers about those with a somalian background, yet 4.2% of the current somali population living in the netherlands has commited crimes, having dropped steadily from 2005 where it was 7.2% with two spikes in 2007 where it jumped to 7.6% (from a 7.1% in 2006) and in 2013 where it jumped to 5.7% (from a 5.1% in 2012)

These statistics only talk about registered refugees so these numbers might not represent the entire refugee population so take it with a grain of salt.

I thought these statistics might be of some use in the current discussion going on and if someone wants to ask anything about the situation in the Netherlands then I'll be happy to oblige.

They also seized the chance of the Syrian Civil War to invade into Syria and capture a large part of her too.
